MILTON WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT
Route 405 South
Milton, PA  17847
(570) 742-3424 (24 hrs.)

George Myers, Office (570) 742-3424, Home (570) 458-6093, Mobile (570) 594-5710, 52 East Main St., Millville, PA 17846
SUPERINTENDENT, Alternate Risk Management Coordinator 

Roberta Brown, Office (570) 742-3424, Home (570) 742-0363, R.R.#3, Box 1740, Jefferson St., Milton, PA  17847, ASSISTANT SUPERINTENDENT, Risk Management Program Manager

The Borough of Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions," Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 on the basis that Chlorine (CAS# 7782-50-5) is handled for wastewater disinfection and stored at the facility above the reportable quantity of 2,500 pounds.  

To assist in providing a safe and healthful work environment for employees and visitors, the Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant has established a workplace safety program.  This program is a top priority for this facility.  The Assistant Superintendent has responsibility for implementing, administering, monitoring, and evaluating the safety program.  Its success depends on the alertness and personal commitment of all.  

Each employee is expected to obey safety rules and to exercise caution in all work activities.  Employees must report any unsafe condition to the appropriate supervisor.  Employees who violate safety standards, who cause a hazardous or dangerous situation, or who fail to report or, where appropriate, remedy such situations, may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including termination of employment.  Some of the best safety improvement ideas come from employees.  Those staff members with ideas, concerns, or suggestions for improved safety in the workplace are encouraged to raise them to the Plant Safety Committee and participate actively on this committee.  In the case of accidents, it is the plan of management that review of such accidents be brought befo

re the Safety Committee for review and correction of any and all hazardous or dangerous situations immediately.
  
With continued commitment and dedication to safety in all aspects of maintenance and operation of this facility, this Risk Management Plan has been compiled and is expected to be strictly adhered to at all times.  With this commitment to safety there have been no reportable release accidents at this facility over the past five years. 

The Superintendent of the Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant has assigned overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the Risk Management Program to the Assistant Superintendent (designated to RMProgam Manager); and has designated the Superintendent as the alternate to serve in the RMProgram Manager's absence.  

Designated individuals such as Operations and Maintenance Foremen have been assigned responsibility for implementing the individual requirements and will communicate information to plant Operators and Mechanics involved in operation and maintenance of the regulated processes, as required.  Report findings will be communicated to the Risk Management Program Manager and, if deemed necessary, scheduled for review at the next Safety Committee meeting.

Communication consists of daily change-of-shift meetings, daily computer operation/maintenance logs, and weekend process control guidelines.  Written memorandums, safety policies/procedures, and trainings are up-dated as deemed necessary for the Risk Management Program to operate efficiently or as federal, state, and local regulations mandate.  All responsible individuals are listed on the management systems flow chart.  (Included in the written onsite Emergency Action Plan).

The Borough of Milton's Wastewater Treatment Plant has one chemical, Chlorine (CAS # 7782-50-5), present at the facility above the reportable quantity.  The total quantity on hand could range as much as 11,800 pounds, packaged in five (5) 2,000-pound (one-ton) co

ntainers and as many as twelve (12) 150- pound (150's) containers.  Two one-ton containers are on-line inside the middle room of the Chlorination Building (located in the Southwest corner of the facility). 

Chlorine is used primarily for disinfection of the effluent water prior to discharge through the NPDES permitted outfall to the Susquehanna River.  The WWTP operates on a 24-hour, 7-day per week schedule.  To reduce the impact a release during handling could have on the community and the environment, it is Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) to changeout chlorine containers/cylinders only during the first shift (6:45 a.m. to 3:15 p.m.) Monday through Friday when the majority of personnel are present at the facility.

A wind sock was placed on top of the Chlorine Building to check wind direction should a release occur.  A loud audible leak alarm inside the building is tied into the plant paging system and, if activated, will set off a red flashing light located on top of the Chlorine Building, as well as the light on the alarm panel in Building 2 (main office building).  

The WWTP's Risk Management Program consists of a written SOP with written checklists from point of delivery of chlorine into the facility through changing of empty cylinders/containers with full cylinders/containers, and placement of the empties at a specific location at the Chlorination Building.

The Milton WWTP Chlorine Standard Operating Procedure (revised May 1, 1999), includes written direction for inspection of all incoming chlorine containers/cylinders for appropriate PA DOT tags, new lead washers, and corrosion.  The container cap is removed on delivery to inspect for corrosion of the valves.  Any container/cylinder not passing inspection at unloading is refused and returned to the delivery truck.  

A Chlorine Change Checklist is a part of the SOP, and is signed and dated by the handlers, listing 19 steps, in order to ensure a safe container/cylinder changeout.  Daily weight of the on-

line containers is recorded at 5:30 a.m., and entered into a chemical inventory computer program to monitor chlorine usage. This weight is also recorded on the Daily Operations Sheets once per shift.  Management personnel review this inventory on a daily basis.

The PA DEP Operator's Outreach Program has presented training at the WWTP every two years.  Our most recent training was held on October 24, 1998 with revisions to the handling procedures completed  May 1, 1999.  This training includes safe handling procedures, review of the handling SOP, application of Chlorine "A" and "B" kits, and general first aid for chlorine exposure.  Instructional training videos are used annually, or sooner if deemed necessary by the Assistant Superintendent. Employee participation in training seminars outside the facility is encouraged by plant management.

Due to this comprehensive training program, detailed safety policies and procedures, and experience of the operators, the Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant has experienced no reportable chlorine leaks over the past five years.

As per EPA's Risk Management Programs Regulation, 40 CFR Part 68, the Milton WWTP complies with OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Regulation 29 CFR Part 1920.38.  Guidance from the Chlorine Institute, Water Environment Federation and the New York State Chlorine Manuals have been instrumental in the development of all chlorine related policies and procedures.  

Should an accidental release occur at any time, the WWTP SOP specifically addresses a Level I release and a Level II release.  Level I releases are defined as incidental releases occurring at the time of handling by trained personnel providing there are no injuries.  A six-step procedure is to be followed as part of the emergency action plan.  

A Level II release would be classified as a release that may cause a threat to personnel, becomes uncontrollable, results in injury, requires assistance of additional person(s), is involved in fire, or may cause

endangerment to the environment or community.  A nine-step emergency action plan is to be followed and would result in contacting the County Emergency Services (911) for an emergency response.  In the event any release should occur, a Chemical Leak Report is to be filled out and submitted to the RMProgram Manager for review and presentation to the WWTP Safety Committee if deemed necessary.  Together, all involved personnel review the situation and correct and revise any deficits in the Policy.

The worst case senario would entail a one-ton container leak outside on the unloading dock of the Chlorine Building where there is no passive mitigation.  The "B" Kit and personal protective equipment are readily available should an incident escalate to a Level II situation involving assistance from trained emergency response personnel.  

The alternative worst case senario would entail a one-ton container leak inside the Chlorine room.  Passive mitigation is present in that the leak would be contained within the room.  The automatic ventilation system would be shut down and the chlorine would be dispersed by ventilation dilution at a controlled rate by trained haz mat personnel from outside the facility.

In April 1996 a coordinated effort with WWTP personnel, local fire companies and the emergency medical service held a simulated chlorine leak drill combined with a confined space rescue.  The response time from the time the 911 call was placed until the container "leak" was stopped was 42 minutes.  This drill impressed upon every participant the importance of a trained response from all collective participants.  The Milton WWTP revised the existing Chlorine Standard Operating procedure at that time.  

As per EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act, 40 CFR Part 355, the Northumberland County Local Emergency Planning Commission has had a Hazardous Materials Off-Site Response Plan in place since December 1996.  

As a result of the recent Hazard Review Analy

sis, it is the intention of the Milton WWTP to budget monies for automatic chlorine shut-off valves for the year 2000.  The appropriate fire extinguishers for a fire involving chlorine (water mist extinguishers) have recently been installed. 

The Milton Wastewater Treatment Plant continues to recognize the potential impact on the community and environment should a toxic release occur and continues to maintain a progressive and comprehensive safety program.  This program includes regular safety meetings and training, an active safety committee that reviews components of the safety program, and adherence to federal, state, and local regulations.
